EARLL MURMAN: OK, so we've
talked about value stream,

and we've talked
about process maps.

In this module, we're
really doing just one thing,

which is to link those
two together in what
we call value-stream mapping.
OK?

And we're going to actually
create a value-stream map
and look at some of--

we're going to
demonstrate what some

of these principles of analysis
of the value-stream map

are and recognize some
process improvement,
using value-stream mapping.

OK, so this is the chart that's
in the middle of your table.

So let's go with this
as the baseline chart.

And now the question is,
given that Sasha and Andy have

a process map, and
they have the data,

how can we combine the
data and the process

map to figure out
quantitatively where

we need to focus for
process improvement?

So value-stream mapping is a
very quantitative activity.

We heard Claudio say,
go see for yourself.

It's going out in whatever
the production process is

or activity is and
actually getting

data that can populate
this process map.

And once people
have data, then they
can make informed decisions.

OK, so we're on the
second stage of the five

stages of lean thinking,
the value-stream stage.
OK.
So a value-stream map is a tool.

It's a tool to use to
identify and eliminate waste.
And I mentioned this.

It's a map with
processed data added.

And what kind of
data do you add?

You add the kind of data you
need to improve that process.
And here are some typical ones.

But you don't have to
feel you have to add--
use all these data.
Use what's necessary.

So usually times
show up in there.

Certainly, if you
have quality issues,
you want to capture those.

You may want to find out
how much is in inventory.

You might need to say, how many
people or spaces being used?

Another one that's often used
is how far you've traveling--

whatever is useful
you want to capture
for your value-stream map.

And then, here are the steps
for doing value-stream mapping.

And again, you've
already heard these.

And this just writes them
down, what you've heard.

You wanted to find, what is
value for your value stream?

Then you create a current-state
map and an as-is map.

So that's what we're going
to do for Sasha and Andy.

We're going to say, what
is their current state?

And they've collected
the data for us.

Then you want to analyze
that map and see,

where is the value-added
and waste activities?

And then brainstorm on
how to eliminate the waste
and add more value.

And then, once you have that,
you create a future-state map.

You remap your process now
where you think you can get to.

And sometimes, you
might create what's

called the ideal state, the
best you can possibly think of.

But that may be too big
a step to take at once.

And so you create--
the future state

may be a step towards
that ideal state.

But you want to get
a future-state map.

And then you have to have
a plan for how you're

going to implement
that future state,

how you're actually going
to change the process.

And we heard a lot about
that at New Balance,

how they actually
moved things around.
They reordered things.
They trained people.

On our tour, Walda said,
we did a little step first.
We changed a little bit.
We got started.

And then we did a
little bit more.

So you don't want
to break the system.

Usually, you're in the
middle of a production
while this is going on.

So you have to keep
producing your units.
OK, so here's our value.

Our customer value is
they want good food,
but they want faster service.

So they're happy
with the quality,

but they want to
get faster service.
And here's our current demand--
50 customers and 100 hot dogs.

Now, I've taken the data that's
on here, the cycle time data,

and just put it next to each of
the boxes on the process map.

And then the quality, we've
also captured quality data.

And so here, we have
10% rejects on this.
But otherwise we're OK.

So that's the kind of data
you might see showing up
on a value-stream map.

And now what we're going to
do is take about 10 minutes.

And the first thing
we want you to do
is to take some colored dots.

And on this map,
just as a group,

try to identify what
these states are red,
that is, pure waste.

There's no value
being added at all.

What steps are yellow, that is,
that they're not adding value

in the eyes of the customer,
but they're needed, given
the current process.
And then what steps are green?

What steps really
contribute to the customer?

So take about three
or four minutes.
Do that.

And you'll find out there
may be some ambiguity.
OK.

There's going to be
some ambiguity, what's

waste, necessary waste,
and absolute waste.

Just do the best
you can, but don't

spend all the rest of the
afternoon arguing about that.

But then, once you find
out what's value-add,

non-value-add, and the red
is wait time here, fill
in the blanks for the time.

And also fill in how
much time of this

is allocated to Sasha, how
much time is allocated to Andy,

and how much time neither
of them are working.

Because we're going to
find out how hard they're

working, how much
of the time they're

actually spending on
executing this value stream.
OK, so go ahead and go to that.

And I'll walk around and see
if you need any help on that.

And we'll then ask
for your answers
on these different times here.
OK, let's see where we're at.

Like the last exercise, we
got some instructor solutions
to hand out to you.

So how much time is allocated,
that neither of them

are spending time
doing it, but it's

taking some time, sit
and wait, or whatever?
AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE]
EARLL MURMAN: 63?
AUDIENCE: Yes.
EARLL MURMAN: OK.
That's good.

OK, was anybody
able to calculate

the total value-added
time in this process?
AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE]
EARLL MURMAN: No?
AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE]

EARLL MURMAN: Why don't we
go and hand out those sheets.
Let's take a look at it.
OK, so this is one way.
What we have is two sheets.

One is this slide, which
is blank in your student
notebooks.

And the other is the
worksheet you were working on.

It's the same data just
shown two different ways.

The instructors
calculated that Andy

is spending 224 seconds of
the total of 446 seconds,

and that Sasha's spending
159, and that's 63 seconds,

the order is just sitting
there in the order-in
or the order-out box.

Now, what's value-added
time and non-value-added?

This is a little
bit more subjective.

The instructor solution was that
taking order was value added.

Now, you could argue, does
Sasha need to spend 60 seconds
taking the order?
OK.
So that's questionable.

But we booked it as
value-added time.

But certainly, that's an
opportunity for improvement.

She is getting the
customer feedback

and seeing if they're satisfied,
and all that kind of stuff.
But 60 seconds is a long time.
OK.

We got 30 seconds is
just sitting there

with nothing being done in
the order in-box for Andy.

Then Andy takes 100 seconds
to cook two hot dogs.

OK, so under our
current process,

we'd say that's
value-added time.

We're delivering
that to the customer.

Could he do it faster
than 100 seconds?
Maybe.
But given the current process--

but certainly, the re-work
is non-value-added.

But now the question is, is that
pure waste or necessary waste?

And we booked it
as necessary waste.

Because if we didn't
check that order,

and it went to the customer
without being properly filled,

then it would not satisfy
the customer's need.

On the other hand, the
customer doesn't really
care about the inspection.

So we added, under
the current process,

it was a non-value-added
but necessary waste.

But one could argue
that it was pure waste.

I mean, you could argue
either way probably.

Same thing here with Andy's
wrapping up the bun--

this is another thing where
Andy's having to check,

does he need to go cook
another hot dog or not?

Well, the customer really
doesn't care about that.

But on the other
hand, if he doesn't

see whether the
order is complete,

the customer is not
going to be happy.

So that's non-value-added
necessary waste.

Here, it's just sitting
there waiting, with nothing
happening, in the Order Out.
So we'll call that pure waste.

And then Sasha does
another inspection.
OK, that's an inspection.

Under our current system,
that's a necessary waste,

because we don't have
quality control working yet.
We add the beverage.

We deliver to the
customer again.

You could argue she doesn't need
to take 30 seconds to deliver
it to the customer.

And then we booked this
clean-up stuff as sort of--

the customer doesn't really
care whether the counter's
cleaned up or not.

On the other hand,
somebody's got to do it.

So it's, again, non-value-added
but necessary waste.
So that's how we booked it.

Again, you could come up
with different bookings.

And we'd be happy
to accept those.

But you have to
make some decisions.

So of that total of 446
seconds, the value-added time's
about 50%.
That's not an unusual number.

Actually, that's somewhat
high for a first time through.

But again, we could argue about
whether some of these things
are really true value-added.

About 32% is necessary
waste and 14% pure waste.

OK, so value-added
time is only about 50%.

Ah-- opportunity
for improvement, OK?

We should be able to do
something better than that.

Let's look at now
the analysis part.

So this is the
value-stream mapping.
Now we're doing the analysis.

We have a total available
time of 240 minutes.
So Sasha's working here--

159 divided by 60
minutes per hour times
she services-- that's per order.
She services 50 customers.

So she's working 132 and 1/2
minutes out of the 240 minutes.
So she's about 55% at capacity.

She's got almost 50%
capacity that she's just not
doing anything.

Andy's a little bit
more overloaded.

We've got the 224 minutes times
the 50 customers, 186 minutes
total.
And I think I see a bug here.
Yeah.

Annalisa, can you note a
correction on this chart?
OK.

Anyway, this should be 186 over
240, which is 78% utilized.

So Andy's working
harder than Sasha.
Now, what do we see here then?
We have an imbalance.
We don't have balanced work.

We don't have them
working at the same rate.

Remember, we talked
about balanced work.

OK, what's the total
capacity they have?

Working with this
current broken process,

they should be able
to service about 65--

on average, about
65 customers a day.
OK?

So that's an example of how you
would do a value-stream mapping
and analysis.

OK, they're Takt time, we
already computed up here.
It was 4.8 minutes.

For 50 customers, they have
to work at 4.8 minutes.

Their cycle time is 446
seconds, which is 7.43 minutes.

But remember that chart that had
cycle time and balanced work--
cycle time and Takt time?

So they've got two employees, so
they can both work in parallel.

So that's why they can deliver
every 4.8 minutes a hot dog.

Because this is
really divided by 2,
because they're both working.
Their production is OK.

They're below their
absolute capacity.

But they've got
a growing demand.
Both of them are underutilized.

But there's utilizations
not balanced between them.

And this is a long time for
making a customer wait to get
a hot dog, seven minutes.

We should be able to
shorten the cycle time.

So in order to get
through next week,

Sasha and Andy are going to
have to improve their process.

Now, we're just going
to do this as a group.

But what are some ideas
how the utilization
can be improved between--
for Sasha and Andy?
Yeah?

AUDIENCE: Sasha should take
the next order while Andy's
preparing [INAUDIBLE]?
EARLL MURMAN: OK.

Well, actually,
she's doing that.

She's taking the next
order while Andy's
preparing it already.

And it's going in
the order in box.
Yeah?

AUDIENCE: You could
pass the order directly
to Sasha [INAUDIBLE].

EARLL MURMAN: Yeah, get rid
of the order intake, right?
OK, that's some value-added.
Yeah?

AUDIENCE: Sasha
can do the fruit.

EARLL MURMAN: Sasha can
do the fruit, right.

That could balance
the work between them.
OK, yeah.
Other ideas?

AUDIENCE: Andy could
have more hot dogs

on the grill than
doing it between.
EARLL MURMAN: Yeah.

AUDIENCE: They're
doing them in series,

and they could be
doing them in parallel.

EARLL MURMAN: Do it
in parallel, yeah.

AUDIENCE: I mean, you
go into Burger King,

and how many are they
cooking at the same time?

Or the next time you sit at
the counter and watch somebody

make pizzas, they've got
about four or five pizzas
going at the same time.
EARLL MURMAN: Yeah.

So do they have anything like
a Kanban system going here?

I mean, maybe Andy could
be putting up hot dogs,

and Sasha, she takes the order,
turns around, takes a hot dog,

puts the fruit,
serves the order.

And Andy's maybe trying to
keep her box about full, not
overfull, but about full.

So they've got this kind
of convoluted process,
where he's--

and this is not
unusual, by the way.

This is the way all
things are done.
They take an order.
They put it on a board.
He takes that order.
He does his thing.
He puts it out.
She does her thing.

But you could be thinking more
of like a Kanban approach,

where Andy is looking
out and saying,

I'll try to keep two or three
hot dogs up there at a time,
or demand's about that level.

And he's in the back
room cooking hot dogs,

and she's serving the customers
and filling the order.

ALLEN HAGGERTY:
Is there anybody--

I just happened to get back
from a skiing trip this weekend.

And on the way up, we
stopped at Burger King.

And on the way back, we
stopped at McDonald's.

And there's a real difference,
an industrial engineering

difference, between
the way they do it.

In Burger King, you
form a sequential line,
and you place your order.

And you walk over here
to try to pick it up.

And in the McDonald's, there's
three or four cash registers,
and it's like a group grope.

Everybody goes up to three or
four of the cash registers.
And it's a different process.
EARLL MURMAN: Yeah.
OK, so some things--

let's eliminate this
pure waste of things

just sitting there
waiting for some action.

Let's get rid of
this inspection.

Let's balance the
work between them.

With a little bit of
simple process improvement

actually using the tools
you've heard about today,

you could go in and probably
triple their capacity.

And the customers would
be getting hot dogs

in 10 seconds or 20, 30
seconds, or less than a minute.
Yeah?

AUDIENCE: How do you account for
how much each of the employees
gets paid?

Is there more value to
having an employee that
gets paid less or paid more?
Because then, it's less cost.

I mean, we're measuring
everything in units of time.

Isn't there a dollars
and cents equivalent?

EARLL MURMAN: Well, there's
a dollars and cents.

But looking at, certainly, from
a lean-thinking point of view,

thinking about how I
can reduce my labor

costs as a starting position,
is taking the sub-optimization.

What you want to
do is look at how

you can use those
employees more effectively

and get rid of the
other costs you have

or the other capacity
problems you have
and reward your employees.

So now, in the end, there is a
limit to everything, of course.

I mean, if you've got
$80,000 hot dog flippers,

you're not going
to be competitive.

But I mean, look what
we saw at New Balance.

Those ladies up there
are making shoes

that are competitive
in the marketplace,
and they're not going to China.
They're probably getting paid--

what's the labor rate
between US and China?
A factor of 20?
AUDIENCE: Sure.
EARLL MURMAN: At least.
But New Balance is managing--

it's a privately held company,
so they're making money.
OK?

And so thinking of just reducing
labor costs as the first thing,

it's just not a
lean-thinking principle.

ALLEN HAGGERTY: Another
thing that Earll's seen out

there-- we took one of
the Arizona State team

through the Apache
production line.

And we actually incentivized
the employees to be--
they helped schedule.

But there's a schedule goal, a
cost goal, and a quality goal.

If they beat that goal and
actually reduce the learning

curve better than what we, in
fact, put in the business plan,

we share that other
run with the employees.

So they're motivated to
beat all three goals.

And it's not just
pushing out the door.

It's got to be high quality,
or the army won't accept it.

So they have to beat
all three goals.

But those teams are
self-managed, and they work.

So you have to put the dollar
incentives on the right things.

And that's delivering value to
the customer-- schedule, cost,
and quality.

But you can, in fact, share
that with the employees,
and they're very motivated.

EARLL MURMAN: So a mass
production thinking

is that the workers are
interchangeable cogs.

And if we don't need them
now, we will get rid of them.

And we'll go down
to the job hall

and hire more,
when we need them.

And the lean approach
is, the workers are
your most valuable resource.

And let them help you make the
system better and compensate
them.

OK, we're about ready
to wrap up this module.

So we've quickly gone
through the first three
steps of value-stream mapping.

Obviously, we've rushed it, but
you've been through a cycle.

Now, tomorrow, you're going
to go through this again
in a Lego simulation.

OK, so what would you
do now where we're at?
Well, you would say--

Sasha and Andy would sit
down and say, let's--

now that we have this data, and
see how bad our process really
is--

let's envision a
much better process.

And you would map that out,
and then you'd go implement it.

For them, that would
be pretty simple.

And you would do it, again,
taking the low-risk steps
first.

You don't want to
break the system.

OK, so why is value-stream
mapping so useful?

And boy, we heard about--
and we heard about it today.
OK?

First of all, multiple people
can visualize the whole process

and see what the whole
process is, as opposed
to just their little piece.

And it's really very hard to
do without some visual tool.
It's hard to describe.

It's hard, if you and I sit
down and say, what do you do?
And what do I do?

It's not the same
as us collectively

sitting down and building
a value-stream map.
Then we really understand it.
It's like active learning.
It's internalizing it.

You can see what the
linkages are in the process.

By working together, you
develop a common language,

so you can communicate
with your workers.

And we saw, up at New Balance,
how they, at least on our tour
that Walda took us on.

She said, if someone is missing
for a day here, or something,

this person can step
in and do their job.

Because they understand
what that job is and how

that job fits in
the overall flow.
OK?

And then, you can find
out where the constraints
are in the system.

So it's, again, a
system-level thing-- find out

where the constraints
are and how

that matches up against
capacity and the wastes
and their sources.
So it's a very powerful tool.
So finally, what are some tips?
Involve everybody.

This isn't something
where you hire McKinsey

to come in and do
a value-stream map
and then give it to everybody.

Because they won't
understand it.
OK?
They have to do it themselves.

And it takes a
little bit of time.
Market takes time.

It takes them away
from their job,

but the payoff is
usually much greater.

You actually strap
yourself to the process.

You walk through it
from beginning to end.

Do it in some environment
like this, where you
can move the Post-its around.

You can collectively
gather around as a group
and look at this chart.

You can put your Post-its here,
and you can all participate.

It's a very flexible
environment.

At this level, a
software tool is not

nearly as effective as just
butcher paper and Post-its.

Now, if you're mapping the
whole value stream of the 787,

you're eventually probably going
to have to get into some form
that you can distribute.

But as a starting
point, you want

to use something
that's very simple.
Use meaningful icons.

Agree on what they
are, so that you're
communicating with each other.
And those are the basic steps.

OK, if you want to get
more information on this,

there's a book called
Learning To See,

that really lays
this whole thing out.

This is really for
factory-type operations,
like we saw at New Balance.

Hugh McManus has
created a version

of that for
engineering, for what we
call product development.

OK, so that's the
value-stream mapping module.
